description:
Tony knows what he's doing! I came here for a workday lunch and it was one of the best slices I've had in the Bay. I had the tomato and cheese pie for $5.50. It was massive, with a good crust (not as crisp as I'd like, but you can't have it all), a generous helping of fresh mozzarella, rich tangy tomato sauce, and fresh chiffonaded basil. Even though this looked like a rather plain pie, it was saucy and gooey and everything you want in a slice. The crust, though it could have been crispier, did have a great bready flavor. I drizzled some of Tony's red pepper olive oil over the top, which added a nice touch. 

The regular cheese slice looked good, but extremely greasy and cheesy-- I wasn't ready for that stomach bomb, and I'd only recommend it to those ready for an extreme cheese experience. But I can wholeheartedly vouch for the  tomato and cheese pie. Great lunch with fast service and a reasonable price point.
author: Bhiravi R.

description:
Located near AT&T park is Slice House. 

Tried the :
Sicilian-  I'd pass on this next time. Just not very tasty all members of our group agreed.

Wiseguy- Housemade Italian Sausage & Calabrese Link Sausage, Tomato Sauce, Ricotta, Hot Pepper Oil, Pepperoni, Mozzarella, Green Onion. The definite winner compared to the Sicilian at least.

Service was friendly, they have a flat screen on the first floor would be nice if they also had flat screens on the second floor of the venue for sports fans. 

All in all a nice venue for a pizza near the ballpark.


If you like my reviews, consider "following" my profile for reviews all across the SF Bay Area . Why "follow" someone?  It causes the person you follow's reviews to tier to top when you pull up a business. I find this very handy when researching venues. 

Rod's Review grading scale explained. Essentially I personally base it on the likelihood of a return visit and I try to be stingy with 5 star reviews since they should be "special" in my eyes. Price/Value also play a role obviously but there are $ and $$$$ littered across my grading scale. 

5 stars - "I'll go out of my way" (approx 6 % of my reviews)  4 stars- "If I was in the area I'd go here and would recommend", (approx 38% of my reviews)  3 stars "Maybe if was nearby", (approx 37% of my reviews) 2 stars -"Would likely not return, Only if you want to go", (approx 16% of my reviews)  1 star -"No thanks, even if I was hungry", (approx. 3 % of my reviews)
author: Rod M.

description:
Best pizza near AT&T hands down.  The mozzarella cheese is of highest quality, and the other ingredients wow, great quality, super busy before and after games, expensive (but the quality), pizza lovers dream, and location.

Highest quality ingredients, great location, clean , a little expensive, super busy at times,  but what do you expect , people love the pizza! Will definitely be grabbing another slice next time I'm at AT&T!
author: Kevin O.

description:
It was a pleasant surprise to run into the Slice House a block away from AT&T Park. The slices are so delicious because it's done by the King of Bay Area Pizza Tony. 
Inside the slice house was spacious and very comfortable. I had the Sicilian and it was good.
author: Juan V.

description: Best by the slice pizza place in the Bay Area. I've only tried the cheese and pepperoni pizza and the cheese slice is the clear winner. $5ish per slice and it is huge. This is the closest to authentic New York pizza I've had outside of New York. Come here if you want the most deliciously amazing thin slice cheap pizza!
author: Sandy L.

description: Sweet Grandma!!! More like sweet Jesus this pizza is so good. I thoroughly enjoy each time I go to slice house because their pizza is delicious. I honestly can't speak for every kind of pizza, I've only had their sweet grandma and a few others. Let me just rave about their sweet grandma because it's a personal favorite-- It's very tasty with the right amount of toppings and flavor. I personally crave this and there's no where else to go for it other than slice house (which also has a location at the market on Van Ness). Thank you for fulfilling my cravings! Sweet grandma you are much appreciated!
author: Anne A.

description:
This was the lunch spot for me and my coworkers.

Pizza was our little treat whenever we got stressed out with work. Single slices were huge! There was always grease pooling in my pepperoni slices but I didn't mind. Pizza has grease, get over it and dab a napkin on it.

Good place for pizza if you're near AT&T Park
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Slice House is a decent stop to grab a nice slice of pizza or two to enjoy!

The restaurant is what one might expect from a pizza establishment, with some sort of sports game playing in the TV. They also serve salads, pastas, sandwiches, and other items other than pizza. 

I came here with two coworkers on an early Thursday afternoon to grab some lunch. I got a slice of their tomato pie and pepperoni pizzas. The slices go for ~$6 each and are very large. They give a separate to-go box for every slice you order. I found the pizza too be fairly average with nothing bad about it and nothing extraordinary either. It's just some good ol' classic pizza that one can't go wrong with.
author: Joshua M.

description: I am a pizza  lover! Lover!!!! Coming here just melted my inner food goblins heart! I ordered the Grandma, fresh Moz, basil, tomato on thick crust! I could have gone for a second! I will be back as soon to try each and everything they have to offer! It's located right next to the ball park so it can also be great before or after games!
author: Julianne O.

description: The combo special for $10, including a salad, slice and soda is a great deal in the City!
author: Andrew H.

description:
Nice little pizza place up the street from AT&T park here in San Francisco. I got 2 slices of pizza. The pepperoni slice was very greasy but good. I liked my second slice better which was a cheese with basil. That was alot less greasy then the pepperoni. 
  A whole pizza is probably better because it's made after you order it while the slices are heated again in the oven.
author: Heath R.

description:
This is a nice intimate place to go to for some pizza slices & pasta when you're in the city and catching a game or concert at AT&T Park.

They do have Happy Hour from Monday to Friday from 3pm-6pm, but not when there's a Giants home game. They do have a Yelp check-in, which is a free soda when you check-in. They also have a Loyalty Card, which you will get a free slice on your 10th visit there. 

I really do like their food and their portions & prices are decent.  The only problem is that their food availabilities are a hit & miss. Sometime they may or may not have the slices that you want, and sometimes they may not be making the pasta that you want. Also, they only make pasta in the evenings; but there was another time when I arrived at 9pm, but they said that they stopped making pasta for the day, even though they don't even closed until 10pm. 

I like them, but the availability of their food is not always reliable. You won't know what you'll be able to get until you get there.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Happened to be in the area for the giants game this afternoon, kids were hungry so we stopped for pizza . For it being noon the Line wasn't bad at all. The man running the register is a real nice guy believe his name is Sean , he was knocking orders out and serving drinks. Helped the kids pick a slice after answering a million questions about all the different toppings. 
The kids and i were amazed how big the slices were . 
I'm my opinion it has to be the best pizza in the city . Can't wait till my next visit .
author: Nick C.

description:
Don't come here during game time (or probably ever.)

Here on a Tuesday night to support the neighborhood. Place was full because the game was going nearby. 

The line to take the money was 3 minutes. Then waited 25 minutes for a slice of pizza, would have been longer if I didn't ask for it cold to take home. 

I told the guy (looks like the manager), "it's been 20 minutes man", his response was "do you see how many people are here? You should have known this when you walked in." Apparently it's okay to wait that long for pizza and tell your customers off. 

If I hadn't paid already I'd be out much earlier and do the hot dog carts across the street.
author: Eusden S.

description:
The nieces were hangry after walking around AT&T Park. Stopped in for a slice since it is only a couple blocks up. 

Kids got cheese slices and we got the slice of the day. The slices are huge and delicious! Way better than I expected. 

Service was fast and the pizza came out piping hot. Highly recommend this place if you're in the area and want a quick bite.
author: Jeanette H.

description: I was walking in SOMA and there were a couple of folks who passed me carrying pizza boxes which smelled great. Turns out they were coming from Slice. Really good pizza and less busy than Sajj. Try it!
author: Sunil R.

description:
Nothing crazy special but solid pizza that beats out a lot of pretty meh SoMA pizza joints. There's a lot of pretty sub-par pizza places here in SF that charge market rate. It's pretty easy to get a greasy slice of disappointment here (looking at you Extreme Pizza). Slices run $5-6 which is pretty okay in my book considering they're huge. I forget what it's called (the grandma?) but the one that's tomato sauce, mozzarella and basil is one of my favs. I recommend eating it at soon as you get it because once the cheese cools it's nowhere near as good. 

Tip: don't try to order on grubhub/yelp or any other pick up service here. Not only does there not appear to be a separate line to pick up, but last time I tried they didn't have my order. I got charged for it, but the cashier just said, "yeah I don't see anything on here. We must not have accepted it." Pretty sure they did. I was charged for it anyway... Regardless, ordering ahead won't save you any time since you'll have to wait in line anyway.
author: Alex R.

description:
Pizza and pasta on point!!! I've been to slice house twice and the pasta, omg, has been consistently delicious. The pasta itself tastes freshly home made and mixed with the a perfect amount of sauce. It's thick pasta, not the typical ones you'd make at home. Add some meat (highly recommend the chorizo) and there you have a perfect bowl of pasta! 

I also loved the Margherita pizza. Slices are huge! So one slice is enough for a meal. If you end up with someone leftover, rather than heating it in the oven, put the slice on a pan over low heat - and you will have a thin, crunchy slice of leftover pizza! Yum yum!
author: Dana Z.

description:
Came here for a quick bite with my friends prior to the Lady Gaga concert right across the street at AT&T park. We were in a rush since we saw the long lines to get in across the street, so instead of eating in we opted for takeout. 

To make things faster, we all ordered by the slice from their display case as the pizza was already pre-made. I ordered a slice of the Sicilian ($6). My friends and I stood around waiting for our orders, and everyone got their order fairly quickly....except me. I looked at the time stamps of my pictures and I waited around 15 minutes for my to-go order. It was honestly a bit ridiculous, especially since the slice was already pre-made in the stand. My friends all ordered one right after another, so we were all really confused why my slice alone was taking so long.

After a while we went up to one of the servers and asked him about my order, and when he checked in with the rest of the folks behind the counter, it seemed like they had forgotten my order. What a bummer!

Because we waited so long for my pizza, we ended up stuffing our faces outside on a bench and didn't really have time to slowly savor the food =/ I remember it being all right but nothing particularly memorable.
author: Dianna H.

description:
The one true pizza.
I LOVE this place.  The pizza is SO good. I'm from New York so I'd like to say that I've had my fair share of pizza, but this place takes the cake (pie?). 
The sauce is good, the ratio is good, the crust is amazing.  They also serve alcohol. What more can you ask for?
I recommend the Wise Guy. The ricotta on it acts as the perfect foil for all the strong meaty tastes. Yum!
A specialty pie will run you ~24 but it's definitely enough for a filling dinner for two.
Overall, I 100% recommend this place and go whenever I'm in the area. 

P.S. If you're the cashier I had that weird "how do you sell your wine? By the cup?" conversation and then served me wine in a cup, I'm sorry!! I had a massive brain fart and my boyfriend won't stop making fun of me now. :P
author: Amy X.

description: Got tickets to go see a Giants game, so pizza was going to be in my plans.  Saw this fine eatery on yelp and the pictures did it Justice! My kid and I ordered the Sicilian, the Tomato Basil  and the Monster Meat slices with a side of Meatballs.  SOOOO Good!  Man, I am not kidding.  The sauce on the meatballs and the pizza was terrific and the cheese was top quality as it melted so generously.  Yes, there was a line.  Yes there were only stools in the upstairs loft.  But when I was eating, I forgot about all these little setbacks.  The food totally overcame any small negatives!  Great job slices!
author: Javier L.

description:
I made the mistake of trying to come here again on Friday night because I had a friend visiting from out of town that really wanted pizza.  I showed up before 9 pm on Friday night, and again the place was closed.  I have no idea when this place is open.  I made the mistake of assuming that because the Giants were playing a home night game, that it would be open at least until 9pm on Friday night.  But nope, I was wrong again. 

The reality is that the pizza here is great but management is mediocre at best, and the service and inconsistent hours reflect that.  This place has the feel, and I can tell from interacting with the staff for years now, that going out at night is more important than having an open store to serve customers.  It's not a big deal at all, but I still won't come back to this location again.  I wish Tony would step in a bring some respectability back to his name.
author: Chimichanga C.

description:
First visit here 

Review: pizza is good but wayyyyyyyyy to greasy my pizza was soaked in grease so much I couldn't even finish it! Pizza slices are huge cute ambience 

Customer service: ? 

Conclusion: I won't visit this location again but maybe another location might be better! I really want to like this place the pizzas look so good and have good flavor but please lay off the grease your gonna kill somebody
author: Sac M.

description: Took these guys a minute to hit their stride here on Second Street but they have settled in and are now a great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Robert M.

description:
We happened upon Slice House by happenstance after one of those Sunday rooftop events at the nearby Hotel VIA.  We got hungry and started walking around looking for anything that was open. That area closes early on Sundays, but they were still serving and we loved it!  They did run out of their Bourbon wings and another type of pizza dough that night so we just ordered some meatballs and a pizza to share. 
They serve some nice beers on draft.  
We sat upstairs and watched whatever baseball game was on that night. Was an awesome pizza experience and I highly recommend you try them!
You also get a free soda upon check in!  Or at least I did btw.
author: Aureliano C.

description:
After complaining and refusing to eat pizza in San Francisco for months (because its not as good as NY) I finally decided to give it a try and I was not disappointed. I ordered take out from Slice House 3 weeks ago and have been hooked ever since. 

I ordered 1 slice of Peperoni and Sausage- which was AMAZING. they actually season the meat before cooking it. It's amazing what a little bit of season can do to a pizza. 

I also got 1 slice of plain cheese which I wasnt crazy about, since it was a little bland. But probably perfect for children with less exotic taste buds.

In addition to the pizza I got meat balls which were super tasty. the only thing that could have made the meatballs better was if they added a small scoop of ricotta cheese to the top. Nonetheless they were super fresh and perfectly seasoned/cooked.

Ever since then, my boyfriend has gotten take out twice. He is totally hooked.
author: Tati C.

description: We came with a group of 30 people. Sean was awesome with getting us taken care of on the 2nd floor. The wait staff was great as well! Highly recommend the slice house, the pizza was amazing!
author: Brandon S.

description:
Great place to grab a slice and beer!  Staff is knowledgeable and the food is well prepared and top notch ingredients.  Walked in after a Giants game and it was empty ( i know bad season! ) but the crew was patient and on spot.  The fried chicken slice was a hit but the deep dish did not impress...
Fantastic beer selection
author: Aaron H.

description:
Maybe you're starving on the way to the Giants game?  

Well no matter.  Now you don't have to wait until you get to the actual ballpark.  You can hit the Slice House on 2nd Street first.

It's kinda perfect.

Since Tony now has 8 restaurants (maybe more...another one could have opened up while I'm writing this for chrisakes) in SF alone, not forgetting that he's inside AT&T Park now, & not to mention the one at Graton Casino, or the one in Las Vegas...he is clearly doing something very right.  

And I certainly tasted that today.  I went for the "slice of the day," & it was fantastic.  Italian sausage, bacon, green onion, & 3 cheeses...on a Holy Craft Beer crust.  One of the best slices that I've had...

...since the last time I had a slice at another Tony's Slice House (in north beach).

This particular location has more seating than NB, but it also has more of a beer pub kind of feel.  I've only come in for this quick lunch, but the vibe is very eat & go.  Not a venue for lingering.

You've got a Giants game to get to anyway, right?

A supreme slice.

4 & 1/2 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: Love that you can get just a slice of pizza and the options are amazing!! The crust was super soft yet crunchy all at the same time and super flavorful!! Love that when you order a piece they then put it in their oven and warm it up so its ooey gooey!! Great spot for a quick bite before or after a baseball game; or take a slice in with you!!
author: Marie M.

description:
Mama mia! Delizioso! One of my fave pizza places in the city, it's solid! I have a weakness for Sicilian pizza, and not many places in the city have it, let alone make it well! My favorite slice to date is the Sicilian. For a slice, it's about $6, but it's a hefty piece!

If you don't like the thickness of the Sicilian crust, you can opt for one of their regular triangle slices, which are just as good! The best regular pizza I had from them had pepperoni, sausage, ricotta (YUM), and green onion, it was the slice of the day!

As for other options, I've tried the meatballs, which are okay. And I love their beer they have on tap!

They have pretty good happy hour specials on slices and beer, but they don't count during Giants games, which is usually the only reason I'm in that area.
author: Eva C.

description: I think outside of New York, San Francisco​ has mastered the ​pizza game.  The lunch deal with a slice plus salad and a drink is a pretty good deal, and this pizza is fantastic. Big, fresh slices with a nice crispy crust and great toppings. They've got a wide variety ranging from regular cheese to Sicilian​ slices. I went with a standard pepperoni and was not disappointed.
author: Ralph B.

description: Yum. Delicious pizza by the slice. Easy to pick up and walk home with and we occasionally order a whole pie or eat there. Love the crust love the pepperoni. Big slices just like you get in NYC. Just wish they were open 7 days a week but I get it in this neighborhood most places cater to the lunch crowd/9-5ers. But for those of us who live in this neighborhood we are just happy to have another spot with something good to eat. Ask for a punch card!
author: Michaela M.

description:
If you read my reviews you know that, as a Brooklynite, I am pizza-obsessed. Since I first stumbled across Arinell's in the mission over 20 years ago, I've sought out new slice joints that can help satisfy my noon-time fix for the world's most perfect food.

So, when my best friend told me they opened up at NY slice-style joint across the street from this apartment by the ballpark, I was intrigued.  Finally, last week we got the opportunity to check it out on our way to the Lady Gaga concert at PacBell.

It was about 5:30PM and the line was out the door and down the street - a good sign and a bad sign since we needed to get to the concert (didn't want the girls to miss anything..). What happened next was pretty amazing to me.

First, the line just zipped along, even though the place was packed and pies were flying around like frisbees on silver platters. Within about 10 minutes it was our turn to order - and since this was my first visit I opted for the standard of all pizzas - pepperoni (note: in NYC proper, most true pizza lovers would say a cheese slice is the standard, but we have lived in CA for quite some time now so basic toppings are acceptable). We also ordered a salad and drinks.

Well, the fast-serve style of order-at-the-counter-and-we'll-deliver-to-your-table really works in a place like this. We hardly got settled when bada-bam the salad shows up followed by bada-bing the pizza arrives, steaming and with that really inviting pizza aroma... mmmm. taste buds waiting...

It was REALLY good. Better than a lot of more expensive pies I've had in SF and elsewhere... including Brooklyn. In fact, one of our girls (who had eaten before we left for the concert and swore she wasn't hungry) took one look at that pie and grabbed a slice to scarf down.  The large pie was enough for the six of use, a slice each plus salad and drink, and we were out of there way before Gaga set foot on stage.

All in all, I can't wait to get back there - and now I understand they have a place inside the ballpark! Ready for my next slice at the Giants game tomorrow!
author: Mike K.

description: Big and delicious slices. I usually get one pepperoni and one of something else... a tomato pie slice (like plain cheese but a bit fancier) or a daily special (love it when they have chicken parm slices!) to mix it up. There's a small but good selection of beers on tap. Hard to avoid the temptation when out for lunch.
author: Bill G.

description:
Fantastic pizza. I have ordered whole pies and picked up a slice and both ways were highly satisfying. Tony uses smaller more abundant pepperoni that curl up and pop with greasy spicy deliciousness. A slice will run ya just shy of $6 but they are BIG and definitely much closer to two slices than one. A whole pizza is fairly priced for the quality and the crust occupies that perfect place in between a Neapolitan and thick crust where it's doughy and firm but still a little crisp. 

The grandma's thick cut slice is also delicious with fresh mozzarella, basil, and tomato, like a super hearty margarita a top of fluffy full flavored focaccia bread with a slight olive oil slick. It's also worth noting they serve one of the best Caesar salads I've have with a thick robust fishy dressing and whole anchovies on top. Wonderful.
author: Sean S.

description:
My wife and I live next door and we seem to stop by Slice House about 1x per week.  Amazing pizza.  I usually get the Sicilian and a slice of the day (whatever it is).  plus they sometimes do this pizza with a chicken parm thing on top that is amazing.  

they also serve beers, which is nice.
author: Eric P.

description: The pizza here is ok. Like that they have options. Regular slices, Sicilian slices, gluten free options and other Italian food options. Location is right by the ballpark so a nice option for reasonable priced eats during game day . It is convenient that you can stop by here to just order slices or an entire pizza. As far as the pizza, it's average for me. I preferred their regular slice/thin crust style over the Sicilian style. The regular slice was large but for like $5 it better be. The Sicilian was also a large slice but a little too doughy for my preference. Didn't get to try the other menu items but the meatballs and some of the pasta dishes looked good. Would I go out of my way to get pizza here? No, but if you want a reasonably priced slice with fast service near the ballpark this is the place
author: Peter P.

description:
Pizza is fine if a bit greasy and overpriced, kinda like an upscale dominos. My one star is for their pathetic, shameless excuse of a salad that I just got. I was grabbing a slice for dinner and wanted some sort of side to go with it. There's nothing really on the menu in terms of small side options so I figured, oh well, I'll just get this pretty expensive Caesar salad and eat the leftovers tomorrow. Look at my attached photo of this "salad". You can say, o but it's a pizza place why would you order a salad. And to that I say fuck off, sometimes I want some greens on the side with my grease bread yknow.

On the upside, however, I now know the perfect place to get an $8 plastic container of neatly arranged iceberg lettuce leaves with a pile of sad questionable anchovies thrown on top.
author: Alina B.

description:
I was genuinely surprised at how delicious this pizza was! I came for lunch with my colleagues and boss and wasn't too sure about it. I mean, we eat lots of pizza at the office and it's easy to mess up pizza. 

We came inside and there's benches, stairs and the counter. They have a special of the day along with salads, pasta salads, and your traditional style of pizza.

I'm a bore and always get pepperoni but it was delicious. The red sauce wasn't bitter or sweet. The crust had a soft bite and fluff (not a fan of thin crusts). You order at the counter and they drop it in the oven and bring it to you.

It's Located a few blocks from ATT park, it's a cool joint to check out before a game. I would definitely go there again.
author: Sierra R.

description: Cool place, tasty pizza (~$5 per slice) and we were able to grab a seat by the window. Fast and friendly service.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Came here for a bite to eat before a Giants game. 

The pizza slices are big and delicious!! They offer wine, beer, wings and more than just pizza. We sat upstairs and enjoyed chatting, eating, and watching the pre-game show on the televisions around the restaurant.

I will be back!
author: Carina M.

description: My friend and I came here for a quick pizza and beer before going to the giants game. We chose this place because it wasn't as crowded as the other restaurants on the same street. It was busy but not too busy, and we were able to find a seat upstairs without any wait. They had a great combo deal, $8.99 for a slice and beer. The pizza wasn't anything special but it was a great stop before a game!
author: Dale D.

description: My go to spot for a meal before a Giants game. They have good tasting pizza and combos for one person or a large party on game day. It can get crowded but there's two-story seating. The upstairs can get a bit warm when the place is packed otherwise fun spot and quick walk to AT&T Park.
author: Mina T.

description:
Best pizza around hands down!

Walked in middle of the day and was greeted by the manager Sean who was super friendly! We had a great chat about the food and SF Giants. Now I know that Slice House has a great pizza/beer deal on game days - hint hint. 

You owe it to yourself to stop by and enjoy some of the great food and atmosphere at least once!
author: Adrien S.

description: Awesome fluffy dough. But the pan pizza is vastly different. Would have preferred all the pizza piping hot out of the oven. And had to have them reheat the last couple slices of the pie. But that's not an issue. Phenomenal taste!
author: Clifford T.

description:
My new favorite place to eat right by AT&T Park, Slice House offers large pizza slices for a reasonable price.  There are always 4-6 different pies available for slices, from regular cheese & pepperoni to thick squares of Sicilian and their ever-changing slice of the day.  And if you feel you need to have some "healthy" food with your pizza, add a salad with the slices.  Our normal order before a game are 2 slices (one each for my wife & myself) and a salad to share.  Each slice is good enough for one person.

I recommend coming here an hour before game time, so you can sit and relax.  There are 2 TVs that are always tuned in to sports stations.  But if you are in a hurry, get your slices to go and walk them into the game.  The Giants have a very fan-friendly policy that allows guests to take in food from the outside (just no alcohol or drinks in metal or glass containers).  Food here will be a lot cheaper (and tastier) than what you can get inside the stadium.

The staff is also very friendly and helpful.  The food runners move fast to get plates to tables quickly.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
When talking pizza, the single cheese slice is the "Gold Standard".  The 100 yards dash of the pizza business.  The Slice House is a 9.3 on the pizza sale of 1-10. 
(figure skating rating, 10's don't happen).

Tony Gemignani is a 12-time World Pizza Champion.  Pizza pies at the "Slice House" are made from quality "00" flour and cooked to golden perfection.  

After talking shop in the "Slice House" after eating there multiple times they were even generous enough to offer me some restaurant quality "00" four to and make pizza at home. 

But, if you want a quality slice you need to stop by the Slice House as my oven isn't hot enough to bake a quality pie.
author: Travis W.

description: Um. Wow. Perhaps the best slice of pizza I've ever had in my 24 years of existence. This place gets busy, especially on game day, but they get their orders out pretty quick. I was pleasantly surprised at how delicious every ingredient was; from the dough, to the sauce and all the toppings.. forget about buying food at the game, the slices here are huge and will keep you fully satisfied throughout the entirety of the game!
author: Ashley A.

description:
Amazing meatball sub. Love that they use garlic bread for the roll. Comes out quick and hot. 

Pretty bust for lunch and during game days, but really easy to get a table for dinner on a weeknight, as much as I've seen. 

Everyone that I've taken there has raved about the pizza, but I've only gotten the meatball sub, so can only comment on that.
author: Brian B.

description: I went in a while back...There were five of us in line to get in at 11:00am, when they're supposed to open. It was 11:18am when I decided to leave; the other people that were in line with me had already left. Too bad they don't adhere to their posted hours. They missed out on business, and those of us with an already short lunch break wasted our time in line for a place that opened whenever they felt like it.
author: Yelper F.

description:
My go to pizza spot!  Slice House offer giant slices of pizza or whole pies.  A massive slice of pepperoni pizza will cost you $5.25- perfect for a quick lunch. The Cal Italia whole pie is an award winning pizza- which you must also try.  I absolutely love their Caesar Salad as it comes with fresh parmesan & anchovies.  Their huge meatballs are a steal at 3 for $5.  This spot usually gets crowded when there's a Giants game going on.  

Tony Gemignani sure knows how to show the world his amazing talent for making Bomb A$$ Pizza!
author: Melanie N.

description:
Everything you love about Tony's - most importantly the delicious pizza pies, but without the crowds and nary a wait. A total score for SoMa!

You need to check out the daily specials. Once it was a sausage and kale pie and the other was a chorizo, cauliflower, and kale - both standout slices. Of course you have everyday dependables like a slice of cheese or Grandma pan pizza slice. Happy hour Monday-Friday from 3-5:30pm where full slices are an amazing $4 deal and half slices just $2. An amazing time to try everything including meatballs and chicken wings. Another lesser know fact is that you can get a combo deal at lunch where a slice, which I forgot to mention are really huge, is paired with a salad for under $10. Such a steal! And the mixed greens salad is something I can happily have for lunch sans anything else. Lovely combination of sweet, sour, and savory with the olives, gorgonzola, walnuts, red onion and balsamic redaction. It's an entree sized salad too. 

The best part is you can easily score a seat here compared to other locations. Folks are friendly and deliver your heated slices to you once you order at the counter. I'll happily grab a couple of slices here before heading to AT&T Park.
author: Jon L.

description: Some of the best pizza I have ever eaten! Worth the price as it is a huge slice and one is enough to keep you full. You can also get 15% cash back on Groupon.
author: Charmaine L.

description: Slice House offers a great HH deal on Giants home game nights - only $8.99 for a slice + draft beer!  I came on a Monday night and to my relief it wasn't too packed.  The slices are humongous and regularly $5-6 each.  Yes it's greasy, but admit it, it's tasty and the perfect food to wash down with a cold beer.  It's not Tony's Pizza Napoletana, but it's good and way cheaper!
author: Beatrice W.

description:
Chronicle Books was giving out 20% coupons to Slice House during their 80% sale, so I decided to try Slice House. I am trying to not eat too much pizza, so I got the artichoke pasta. It was good and came with slightly dried tomatoes and a cheese I couldn't put a name on. I also got a Boylan ginger ale. With the 20% off, total came to $10. The restaurant has a nice interior and atmosphere with pop rock playing on the speakers.

*Review 1100
author: Denise C.

description:
Had the Sicilian slice and it really filled me up. Super delicious, and on the greasy side. I went in for lunch the next day and tried to order a pasta, but they said they don't do pasta during lunch. :(

So I got another Sicilian. Lol.
author: Alex K.

description: Just good pizza! Flavorful, great service, clean. See you next time we catch the Giants game!
author: Sherri L.

description: I'm really disappointed. Two evenings in a row we tried to go here and both nights they just decided to close early. Last night, (Wednesday) we got there at 6:30pm and they were closed and tonight (Thursday)  we got there at 7:50pm and they were closed. Tonight there was a note on the door that said they were closed at "discretion of management".  None of these closings are consistent with their hours on Yelp or on Google (which by the way, the hours are different on both sites).
author: P D.

description: Slice house is great!! Love Tony's pizza so having his pizza closer to me when I don't want to go all the way to SF is awesome.
author: Bob R.

description:
Simple and good. Not crazy on flavor. 3.5 I'd say. I came here with a friend of mine that had visited the area and we chose something close by to where he was staying. The girl at the front was really friendly which is always nice, and the workers extremely helpful.

He had gotten 3 slices of pizza, and an order of wings. I picked up a panik and grandmas slice. The prices were a little higher than used to but for slice places around the city it seemed like it was on par for the most part. The panik didn't wow me to be honest, but the chicken on it had a good flavor and good consistency. Typically if a place uses chicken I worry it turns out a weeeeeeee bit dry but theirs was fine. I like the crust for the grandma the best out of what I ate though I wish I could've added some other toppings to it. Like roasted garlic, basil, or sauteed wild mushrooms would've brought the flavor a step up. But that's just personal preference. I had one of the wings also, it had some sort of bitter flavor at the end that took away from the taste. Not sure what that was from, could've been some type of korean bbq sauce that was used or it was hoisin based. 

I'm pretty sure I'd get grandma's again if I came by although I'm not sure I would spend the price point to customize it entirely. We'll see how it goes though if I'm in the area again.
author: David C.

description: Perfect place to grab a slice of pizza and beer before a Giants game. The location is walking distance from the stadium. They have plenty of seats, but, if there is no room, pizza is portable so you can just take it with you on your walk back. :)
author: Nichole M.

description:
Chill lunch spot with really gooooood pizza with hearty-sized slices.     

I enjoy the loft area for a little less door traffic from the main entry. 

Tasty!
author: Shawnee J.

description: My boss and I have our dinner here. The pasta was a good size serving enough for 2 people. It was delicious and tasty.
author: Emilia F.

description:
My favorite spot to grab a slice of pizza. So good! Wish they delivered. 

Also a great place to eat before or after hitting up the ballpark for a Giants game.
author: Zell C.

description: Was craving pizza on my last day in the City and didn't want to travel too far from the hotel. Hit up yelp and ended up here.  I've seen some reviews say the pizza was undercooked, but that was not my experience. We ordered a full pie, half pepperoni and half cheese and olives.  I'm not an olive person but the olives they use here are green, so if that matters to you then take note.  Aside from that, the place was clean and the pizza was great! I will definitely be back if I'm in the area again.
author: Lacey M.

description:
This location has 80% of the wonder of Tony's Pizza Napoletana (in North Beach) but without the dreaded wait time. You really can't go wrong here! The service is great at this location too.

Gluten free notes: They offer the gluten free whole pizzas here too (no slices). Not as extensive of a menu for choice, but they have all the basics!
author: Shannon Z.

description: Walking back from a Giants game and the smell of a delicious slice of pizza from someone walking by brought us in. Pretty cool you can still get it by the slice. It was around $5 for a decent sized slice of cheese. The sauce was delicious and the dough crispy and tasty. It only took a minute to heat it up and we were on our way.
author: Francine B.

description:
Absolutely awesome pizza place. If you want chill atmosphere & excellent pizza look no further. I'd recommend trying slices as they are huge. The beer selection is solid too and the staff is helpful.

Tip: 3 individual slices are the same price as artisan pizza. So if you want something simple, like cheese or pepperoni it's less expensive to get slices... you will get the same amount of pizza.
author: Anatoly K.

description: The best pizza in San Francisco. Yummy to both my 8 year old son and to his mama and papa.
author: Jonathan R.

description:
These guys have a pretty good pizza and beer deal located a few blocks from the AT&T Park. They sure do get a lot of business during baseball games. We heard about the $8.99 pizza and beer deal so we decided to drop by here after the game. Instead of the individual option, we opted for two medium/large pepperoni sized pizzas and two pitchers of beer to be shared among 7 people. The pizza came out in less than 10 minutes and it was so good, especially when you've been drinking and hungry all day. The slices were pretty tiny, so I'm thinking the individual pizza slice with beer would have been a better option. Total came out to around $9.30/person. The selection of beers are not your watered down domestic kinds, I don't know the exact names of the beers but they definitely weren't your typical blue moon, shocktop, bud light, etc type of beers. In the future I would stick to the slice deal since the slice looks huge. The restaurant filled up quickly after we arrived. 

I would definitely tell everybody who are going to the Giants game about this place. Such a great deal in comparison to the steep prices at the park!
author: Rita K.

description: Great tomato basil pizza. I am from India so this was the best pizza I have ever had in my life. Might not hold true for others :)
author: Akshit J.

description: Their website and yelp says they close at 8 PM so we went at 7:20 on a Saturday. The door was locked and nobody opened it even though there were customers and staff inside. Plus no one answered the phone!
author: Sweta P.

description: Best pizza I ever ate!! Staff is nice. Going here every week to do something good for myself.
author: Leonard J.

description:
Every pizza I've tried was good, but my favorites are: the Sicilian since it's pan-style and with pepperoni and sausage; the Wiseguy since it has green onion and hot pepper oil; the Popeye since spinach and Ricotta worked well together.

The interior remained basically the same since it changed from Ironside. Still cozy with bench seatings or tables for two and more. They have a good selection of beers on tap too!

Located near AT&T Park, easy to find, decent parking with meters or try some of the nearby alleys for one hour parking. One of the best places for lunch, and likely dinner.
author: Peter L.

description: The pizza was awesome! The staff was so nice even when my kids had changed their minds for drinks! We were out of towners and would definitely come back.
author: George P.

description:
This is my go-to neighborhood pizzeria... Not because it's my favorite, but because it's close to my office and pretty much the only (pizza) game in town for a quick-fix meal.

I typically go for the pizza by the slice and a beer.

The Beer
The selection of beers is pretty big... But... I suppose if you're a fan of the typical stuff that you'd find in any grocery store then you'll do fine. Overall, the selection isn't worth writing home about. 

They do have about 4 on tap with the rest in cans and bottles. So if you're looking for beer, there are far better venues in the area.

Today, I opted for a pint of the Zen Sudwerk - One of the better options available. ~$8

The Pizza
The pizza is your garden variety, over-the-top spicy, soggy, greasy, kinda chewy thin crust that requires a fork and knife.

Today's daily special (pepperoni and sausage) was $6 per slice.

After tax, $15.23.

It's certainly not the best, nor the worst. YMMV.
author: Caine H.

description: Got the tomato basil slice, and it was AMAZING. Usually, when I get a pizza, it's always lacking in sauce, and if I ask for extra sauce on the side...they give it to me cold (I'm serious...I never get why). But here, they add extra sauce on top (nice and warm, thank you), so problem solved. And guess what guys, the sauce is frekin' delicious. The only thing that concerned me was consistency. Came back another day, and the pizza dough tasted a bit off. Perhaps I was comparing it to the perfect experience before, or it was simply an off-day for them. Whatever it may be, I still ate my slice and left happy. Entire pies are a tad expensive, and an individual slice at $6 can feel hefty - but honestly, a slice is all you need. The atmosphere is nice and lively, and the place is tucked away on a quiet corner of 2nd street. Didn't feel unsafe walking there alone at night. A worthy experience!
author: Henna S.

description:
Pizza is fantastic! Best in the Bay Area and walking distance to AT&T Park.
Grab a slice and a beer after the next Giant's home game. You won't be disappointed
author: Frank P.

description:
Like everyone else, there are some restaurants out there that I absolutely adore.  Places that I'd be willing to endure a longer wait for than others (to a certain point, anyways).  However, despite how much that love extends to Tony's Pizza Napoletana, our hunger simply didn't have the patience to wait two and a half hours for a table.  The alternative?  Literally the next best thing, though not the next door location - Tony's Slice House!  

Located just a few blocks over from the ballpark, Slice House's location is great - clean, plenty of seating (both upstairs and down), and nearby parking (when there isn't a Giants game).  Most importantly though, the food is nearly just as good.  True, the menu isn't nearly as varied, or extensive, as Tony's Pizza Napoletana's, but I doubt there's any pizza restaurant out there that has a menu as awesome and amazing as theirs.

-- ST. GERMAIN WINGS...$10
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/slice-house-san-francisco-3?select=quITzUH7D29meYuNMPtuhA)
I was worried they were going to taste like generic buffalo wings, but, thankfully, they were better than that.  The sauce added a bit of spice and sweetness, yet it didn't overpower the wings.  Also, while each one was decently meaty, at $10 for six pieces, the dish is a little pricey for wings that are decent, but not amazing.

-- CAESAR SALAD...$9
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/slice-house-san-francisco-3?select=0y8QOS8ecPv2fqK9M5RsSw)
Alternatively, this starter was much more worthwhile.  The lettuce was crisp and fresh, the dressing had just the right tartness, and the anchovies were delicious (and not drenched in oil).  Funny how pizza joints like Amici's and Slice House do Caesar Salads better than some restaurants.

-- SWEETIE PIE - White Pie, Prosciutto, Arugula, Mozzarella, Formage Blanc, Sweety Drops, Parmigiano...$22
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/slice-house-san-francisco-3?select=LD56rp1mONR3t1u3oYbkZQ)
They're so generous with the toppings!  Especially with the prosciutto and arugula, though perhaps a little heavy on the latter for some (I liked it).  I liked how they didn't skimp on the cheese either, and the white sauce was pretty flavorful.  The crust was a little thick, but it was fine, seeing as how it's Tony's/Slice House does really well with all of their pies.

-- THE WISEGUY - Tomato Sauce, House Made Italian Sausage, Calabrese Link Sausage, Ricotta, Hot Pepper Oil, Natural Case Pepperoni, Mozzarella, Green Onion...$22
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/slice-house-san-francisco-3?select=GjQr6XQcWZBAQLP2PmZqrQ)
Of the two we had, this was my clear favorite.  I'm not super high on red sauces, but this one was good.  It helped that the pizza was so meaty and I really liked how juicy the sausages were.  I thought the ricotta would be a little too heavy, but it blended well with the rest of the flavors, especially with the hot pepper oil!

As far as service goes, it was clear the staff was undermanned when we dropped in for dinner (several tables uncleared, lack of clean utensils at stations), but you could tell they were doing their best while maintaining a friendly demeanor.  Beyond that, the only other semi-downer was how the menu doesn't include Tony's famed Margherita pizza.  For that, I guess I'll just have to wait.

FOUR AND A HALF STARS rounded up.  Not quite as good as Tony's Pizza Napoletana, but considering the lack of wait and quality food, it's worth the extra half star.
author: Mike L.

description:
I took a large group of high school students here while chaperoning a field trip. The food was fantastic, even by Tony's standards. Obviously you want to order the pizza, but don't miss the meatballs, which are better than my mom's (who does not know how to yelp).

The manager made planning the meal super easy. He let us pre-order the pizzas so I could avoid the confusion that comes with 18 high school students attempting to agree on what toppings they want. And while we were there, he treated us like family. 

I'll be back many many times!
author: Michael M.

description: Best pizza I have ever had. Loved the tomato pie and the Pigman. We also had all 3 pastas and they were simply amazing. Highly recommend!!
author: Chris M.

description:
Had a groupon for Slice House, so decided to try it out this past Saturday.  I wasn't use to this type of pizza (since I prefer a thin crust new york style), but, it was good.  

Pros:

1.) Great parking.  Lots of street parking spots and if you go in the evening, street parking will run you approximately, $1.27 (including transaction fee).

2.) Nice layout.  Has the feel of modernized round table, but more so upscale.

3.) BIG portions and tasty food.  We had a Wise Guy (pizza) with garlic bread, meat balls, and pasta salad.  The meat balls were yummy, same with garlic bread, but not a fan of the pasta salad, the gf really liked it though.  As for the pizza, the Wise Guy felt like a mini deep dish pizza and didn't like the extra sauce on top, but the pizza in general was tasty with a lot of meat and was impressed with the crust they used which could withstand all the toppings.  

Cons:

None.

Overall, good food and reasonably priced (total came out to $51).  I definitely want to come back and try their thin crust pizza.
author: Mike M.

description:
New kid on the block.

Slice House is the brainchild of Tony Gemignani, a well-known champion pizza maker and pizza thrower. He is also the first and only American to date to win the World Champion Pizza Maker at the World Pizza Cup in Naples, Italy, where he was the first non-Neapolitan to achieve such glory. Since then, he's opened up a lot of popular and successful pizza joints in North Beach and all over San Francisco, Sacramento and Las Vegas. He's also got one joint inside AT&T Park for all you Giants fans. I'm sure Timmy would love that joint after hitting the peace pipe. 

After attending a meeting at the ballpark, we were walking back to work and we were all getting hungry. We were undecided on where to go at first until we stumbled in front of this place. You can't go wrong with pizza so that three of us all walked in and started perusing the menu. You can get a slice or the whole pie or pan as they describe it ranging from Classic American, Italian, Sicilian and Neapolitan. They also have meatballs, chicken wings, garlic bread, salad, paninis and pasta to choose from. We also each chose a slice (or two) of our own and a plate of meatballs to share with the group. 

Seating is self-service so you can choose your own table and make sure to grab the utensils and some water at the station. Our pizzas arrived in a jiff and thank goodness since we were starving. I ordered the Grandma and it was a perfect name as it was like comfort food. These are not thin-sliced pizzas as the dough is fairly thick, but it's very light and fluffy. You can tell the sauce is made from fresh tomatoes and not from a can based on the texture and wonderful flavor. And the ingredients are portioned evenly giving it a good balance from dough to sauce to fillings. The meatballs were delicious and seasoned well. It was moist, meaty and manly. 

It's another good addition to the neighborhood (no surprises here) as it's reasonably priced and they even have a Sunday Brunch special. Take note that their hours of operation tends to change depending on the Giants schedule. 

Good quality pizza at a good value. Also good for dine in and take-out.
author: John G.

description: My wife's pick!!! I gotta say I was in the mood for a burger but I'm sooo glad she liked the smell of this place.  Staff is super friendly and the pizza....omg... I love it!!!
author: Michael M.

description: The focaccia pizza is really good however this place is really run down the bathrooms just disgusting and I think it could be a lot cleaner In general!!
author: Soph C.

description: The pizza here is to die for. It's delicious, flavorful and made in coal fire ovens. The sauce and dough are well made and neither over power another. They have many different flavors, thin crust, pan crust and many other options on their menu. I Highly recommend this place. You can either dine in their resturant next door or just go in to the slice house for a quick bite. I will definitely be coming back here for a slice next time i visit San Francisco.
author: Elizet S.

description:
I decided to stop here for some lunch during my break from work.  I paid $5 for a slice of cheese pizza to-go.  Before I delve into how the pizza itself was, let me break down some facts about this place:

* You can either wait in line and get your orders to-go or you can eat-in by sitting at one of their tables.  (They have seating both upstairs and downstairs.).  Regardless, you need to first get in line, place your order and pay.
* Don't think that it's just a place that serves only pizza, based upon its name.  Their menu is quite extensive with Italian fare -- they have pasta, antipasti, salads, focaccina (panini sandwiches), garlic bread, meatballs, Italian desserts (i.e. tiramisu, spumoni, etc) and more.
* Furthermore, in addition to traditional pizzas (i.e. cheese and pepperoni), they make pan pies, speciality pizzas with a number of fancy ingredients and artisan pizzas too.
* Drink wise, they have coffee, soda and water.

Pros:

+ Despite the line, transactions were quick and I was in and out in ten minutes.
+ Aside from ordering a slice of cheese, I also wanted garlic bread.  However, the cashier informed me that due to the power outage from the previous day, they had been unable to bake any in time for the lunch rush.  She was very apologetic about it and I understood as my office building nearby experienced the same power outage.
+ Despite the price, you definitely get your money's worth.  The slices here are HUGE.  And they've been very tasty too.

Cons:

- The only negative was that the slice I ordered was swimming in grease.  Yes, I know that pizza is known for being greasy.  But I had to pretty much blot the pizza with several paper towels to remove the excess grease.  I don't have a problem with greasy food, but I tend to get an upset stomach whenever I eat something that's overly greasy.

Overall, I'm impressed.  I'm sure I'll be back soon.

4 stars
author: Michael F.

description:
Some of the best pizzas I've ever eaten in my life have been here. Beautiful crust, beautiful sauce, and beautiful toppings. Beautiful tiramisu, too.

That being said, the reason I'm not giving this place more than three stars is because the last few times I've come in, my pizzas have been undercooked. Like, between the sauce and the bottom of the crust is a layer of half-cooked, slimy dough that I can scrape off with a fork.

This kills the structural integrity of the crust and makes the pizza taste worse. And considering that a slightly overcooked pizza usually tastes better than a slightly undercooked one, this says to me that the place is becoming more concerned with quickly pushing out pies than it is with delivering a consistently excellent product.

A disappointing and fatal rookie mistake in an otherwise masterfully executed pizzeria.

Front-of-house staff here has always been mildly unfriendly, but this place used to be so good you wouldn't even care. Used to be.
author: Oliver K.

description:
There should be a San Francisco law introduced that requires amazingly tasty pizza slice joints to stay open an hour past bar closing on Thursday-Saturday.  The pizza here is a great, about the closest to a NY slice I've had.  But it's just not the same popping in sober during lunch or before a baseball game.  This food would taste even better as the last stop between a night out and my bed.

Cheese Slice: Having lived in Manhattan for 6.5 years, I really miss those casual and quick slices.  No toppings, no folding, just a firm bottom crust (that doesn't flop down) and parmesan cheese, red pepper fakes, oregano and garlic salt on top.  Most pizza by the slice is pretty bad in San Francisco.  Besides Tony's, Arinell is the only tolerable one out there.  At Slice House, it's almost like being back in NYC.  The crust is a little fluffier and they're a little more generous with cheese, but the sauce is spot on and the bottom of the crust is nice and firm from the oven reheating.  No garlic salt in sight unfortunately.  They pre-sprinkle on the parmesan cheese and oregano, which could be an issue for some, but is fine by me.

Grandma Slice: Golden Boy is a tad better for Sicilian-style square slices.  But this was tasty.  Loved the fresh mozzarella and ample portion of sauce.  Tasty,  but probably better to save your limited stomach space for more NY-style slices.
 
Meatballs: These are pretty awesome.  Order a Cheese Slice and a side of 3 Meatballs and you have a hearty meal for $10 (...a rarity in SF).  There is so much nice red sauce in the bowl that your pizza crust can become a bread stick with tons of sauce leftover for your meatballs.  The meatballs themselves taste meaty (i.e. not much filler) and firm, but not too firm.
author: Adam B.

description:
Pigman - 3/5
Wise guys - 3/5
Killing Zoe - 2/5
Cal italia - 5/5

Overall, "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description: Sunday afternoon 4:30pm, empty restaurant, the staff of Slice House decided to play Metallica at more than 80 decibel over the speakers, i am not kidding! I came to relax, but it ended up waiting at the most uncomfortable restaurant i have ever visited. Thank you for the headache!
author: Mirko W.

description: I want to give it more starts but the oil literally got my stomach tumbling. Will try again when it's not take out and will update if it's better next time. Some times the oil takes away from flavor and I did not reheat pizza after receiving it. Cute place.
author: Alex L.

description:
I'd been craving pizza all week. Decided to finally make the journey to Slice house to satisfy my craving. On Friday, July 17th after 2pm, I walked the 2+ miles roundtrip for some pizza!

*Pepperoni ($5.25)
*Tomato pie with cheese & basil ($5.50)

This totally hit the spot! Both slices had the wonderful chew I love about Tony's pizza. The pepperoni fulfilled the carnivore in me with it's delicious meaty flavor. I adore cheese and basil, so that slice provided a great contrast to the pepperoni slice. I was in heaven! Plus, these slices are fairly large, so I had half of both for lunch and the remaining halves for dinner.

Thank you Tony's for fulfilling my pizza craving. I just wish you were closer to my office!
author: Elena N.

description:
Not only is this the best pizza I've ever had in California, it's the best pizza I've had in quite a while anywhere.

Slice House had some bomb specialty pizzas available by the slice. The Grandma slice was killer and reminded me of the slices I'd get by my college in NY, only better. The slices were big and hearty, and the sauce on them was zesty and flavored wonderfully. One of the weak spots I've found in California pizza in general is that the sauce often tastes just of tomato paste. Luckily, this was not the case here!

I was lucky to stop by here when I did, because there wasn't much of a crowd. With how good it was, I bet it could get pretty packed, especially after a Giants game lets out.

Stop by, grab a beer and a couple different slices off the rack. You will NOT be sorry!
author: Michael R.

description: One of my favorite pizza shops in the city. Amazing slices... Love the pepperoni and cheese slices! and their meatballs are fantastic too. Prices are reasonable and service is fast.
author: Shirin O.

description: The owner Sean reached out an explained what happened. I'm inclined to believe them since we never had a problem with them before, but several with Caviar. He sent over a gift card to make amends which is pretty much the best way this could have been handled so 5 stars for great customer service and great pizza. This is one of my favorite pizza places in the city (my work's favorite too) so I'm happy we can continue to order from here, though it definitely won't be through Caviar!
author: Kajal G.

description: 2 registers on the counter, only one of them open with a line out the door. 30 minutes is just too long to wait for a to-go slice of pizza.
author: Dan P.

description: Stopped in here for a couple slices with my husband and was amazed! The pizza here is so delicious. The rust is so crispy and perfect! I used to live in nyc so I know about pizza and this place has really goooood pizza! Can't wait to go back for more!
author: Rachelle K.

description:
Ordered wings and a side of meatballs.  The 6 people I was with got their food, and 10 more mins went by.   Flagged the server down and he said he would check on it quickly.  10 more minutes go by and nothing.  Went up to the counter to ask, then they tell me the fryer went down and the wings weren't coming.  I asked about the meatballs and they said, oh yeah that's ready - would you want that now?  Said yes obviously.  Asked what they were going to do about the wings if they were going to get me a refund and they said someone was going to come by.

10 more minutes went by again no one came to me - asked them again about the status and they responded to me like I was inconveniencing THEM.  Manager finally came by 10 MORE minutes.  At this point I was upset but kindly asked for them to refund both the wings and the meatballs, which he said, "ok".  He comes back and he only refunds me for the wings.  

Basically, they took my money, were never going to tell me that I was never getting my food - not even the 2nd thing I ordered and treated me like I was irritating them when asking them about it.

Never again.  Bye.
author: R A.

description:
Pizza.. meh. 

People say it's better than real New York slices? Not even close. 

Prices are so expensive, but I guess the portions are huge. But pizza doesn't need to be that huge. 

French fries ARE DELICIOUS. Super crispy, awesome flavor, and big portion. 

The ambiance is nice, especially if you're here to watch sports with a full house. 

Also, the tall guy at the register was kind of douchy. He either misheard or it was my friend's mistake but a french fry order was missed. Either way, he had an attitude when I asked about when the second order of fries were coming out. And he wasn't very helpful when we had questions about the pizza and the menu. 

Would only meet friends here if they suggested, otherwise I won't be back.
author: Priti K.

description: Tasty pizza with nice crunchy whole wheat crust; I'm a fan of the pepperoni, grandma's (or anything that has the semi-sweet teardrop tomatoes!), or whatever special gourmet pizza they come up with. Ingredients seem fresh and slices are generous in size - essentially getting two normal slices, which explains the higher pricing as well. Open relatively late and popular hangout during local games (Giants, Warriors) with lots of TVs to watch. Upstairs is quieter and nice - usually pretty empty during the day. Can also order ahead and pick-up (whole pie or warmed-up slices). Expanded menu with salads, pasta, and wings are good, as well. Overall, a nice, reliable pizza restaurant to have in the neighborhood.
author: Sarah T.

description: Been wanting to try this place but unfortunately they ran out of pizza for the day. Guy working there wasn't very empathetic and kept calling me "bro". Guess I'll never try their pizza since I won't be going back.
author: Nelson W.

description:
Oh man, I just walked by the breakroom at work and passed a box of cold pizza.  No way I could resist it...so i snuck a slice.  Omg, even cold, this pizza is so good!!!  I can't imagine how it tastes toasted or on site.  

I'll be ordering them for future events at work!  Crispy/chewy crust, nice, light, fresh toppings.  

Total worth the cheat day!
author: Vi Y.

description:
Awesome place to go for a slice of pizza before/after the Giants game- and a must try for any pizza lover! I finally got to check out Tony Gemignani's pizza, and I wasn't disappointed. We came in as a gigantic group a quarter past noon on a Wednesday before the Giants afternoon game, and they weren't super busy at the time, although there was a fair amount of people coming in and out during our order. Since I was expensing the meal, we had a 20+ person order and the staff was fantastic and really accommodating. We were able to order and get our food in 20 minutes or so, which is impressive. I was sad that the variety they have available for purchase by slice is very limited (only Cheese, Pepperoni, and Tomato Pie w/Cheese & Basil for the traditional crust, and the Silician and Grandma on the focaccia bread). I tried:

-Cheese Slice ($5, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=-RcFX1StRVh2qHxiX4EWRQ&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): This was a very solid cheese pizza, and I loved that the crust on the middle part of the pizza wasn't soggy and just collapsed when you picked up the slice. The cheese had just the right amount of grease on it, which gave it flavor but didn't make it too oily. Recommended!
-Tomato Pie w/Cheese & Basil ($5.50): Also very solid, although I always wish there was more fresh mozzarella on this type of pizza. However, I liked the sweetness of the tomato sauce. Recommended.

I will definitely have to come back and try some of their combination pizzas, such as the Cal Italia, which won the Gold Medal on the Food Network Pizza Champions Challenge, and the Pigman, since it sounds delicious. They also have a decent (although small) selection of beers on tap, but they also have a variety of bottled beer as well. Parking in this area on game day and during the weekends can be difficult, but there is some street parking available.
author: Amy D.

description:
Ordered a medium Popeye pizza.
It had good flavor to it and great taste with good selection of beers. Would definitely go back here.
author: Sailaja B.

description:
Went back for another try after Tony's management reached out. Slice of the day was great, they put the Barca game on the big screen upstairs for us, and the service was with a smile from each member.

Very glad I don't work next door any more, I'd be huge. 5 stars next time I go back and confirm my first visit was just a fluke.
author: K M.

description:
Many people in the city compare this place to Tony's in North Beach. While Tony's offers great pizza, slice house is a great option for a quick bite before a game. The options are fairly pricy. I went with the Cal Italia which featured prosciutto and multiple cheeses. The dough is probably the best part of the pizza, especially when fresh. Both doughy and crunchy, the toppings never fell off and provided great stability to the pie. 

My only concern with slice house is the price of a full pie. A large pepperoni pizza was nearly $40. The cal Italia I ordered only had 6 slices for about $22. While I do think that it is fairly affordable, the price is fairly steep.
author: Joel Christian A.

description:
Is pizza wunderkind Tony Gemignani in danger of overexposure? Yeah probably but it's not like he's sold out and become a Food Network whore like Guy Fieri whose most current culinary connection is the excessive amount of carbs he can stuff in his ample mouth. Like many in our fair city, I became a fan when he opened his first San Francisco place, Tony's Pizza Napoletana, back in 2009. That's when my friend Maggie organized a birthday fête for me, and we tried a number of different pies including my eventual favorite, the Cal Italia with four Italian cheeses, prosciutto, a Croatian sweet fig preserve and a liberal drizzle of a balsamic reduction. Fantastico and then Jamie W. and I recently tried Tony's other North Beach Capo's for the first time.

Fantastico seconda parte. And then we found out Tony was taking over the former Ironside space on 2nd which thrilled us since he's now in our 'hood. This may be his third San Francisco operation, but he has since expanded his pizza empire from here to Vegas. Fantastico terza parte? Jamie and I decided to give it a try this past Friday and were surprised to find it nearly empty at about 6PM since there's plenty of beer on tap (photo: http://bit.ly/1byJErQ). I got here a bit earlier than Jamie, so you'll probably never guess what pizza I ordered for the two of us. The Cal Italia, of course (photo: http://bit.ly/1PQiKek). The ingredients were the same, but the crust was different. He bills it as "Ancient Grain Pizza" which represents a blend of Tony's double-zero flour, spelt, semolina, sprouted grain & whole wheat.

The result was probably healthier than the original but not quite as satisfying because of the chewier texture. You would think that would be enough for two mean with healthy appetites, but we were mindful of the name of the place, Slice House. With that in mind, I ordered a $6 square of the Sweet Grandma's Pizza, a Sicilian-style creation of which they make a limited number daily. It's really more a thick foccacia-like loaf with a sauce made of sweet, vine-ripened tomatoes ladled on top with mozzarella, garlic, oregano and pecorino (photo: http://bit.ly/1JwYGNf). While I appreciated the freshness of the ingredients, the breadiness overwhelmed me somewhat, so much so that for the first time, I could not finish a slice of Tony's pizza.

Jamie liked his $5.25 slice of the Pepperoni, and the slice was frankly enough for two with an abundance of meat (photo: http://bit.ly/1GCBVXt). My one complaint was the amount of grease that accumulated on the cheese probably because it spent some time saturating in the display case. Even with the focus on pizza, there were plenty of other items on the menu - salads, a couple of pasta specialties, paninis and apparently a meatball sub to die for according to the server who was pushing it hard. I have no doubt that Tony will bring 'em in again although I hope he doesn't go into a franchise zone with his award-winning pizzas. Not worried yet, but I'll be back to monitor it. After all, someone has to make sure of the quality on a regular basis, right?

FOOD - 4 stars...Tony is a pizza artist but some of the North Beach pizzazz seems missing here
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...good use of the loft-like setting Ironside struggled with
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...cordial enough
TOTAL - 4 stars...a slice of Tony's is worth a pound of cure...or somethin' like that, goombah
author: Ed U.

description:
one of my best pizza places in SF. love how chewy the dough is. i recommend the followinng pizzas:
-cal italia
-crazy 8
-wiseguy

i don't recommend their mixed greens salad. it was all mixed greens and had very little of anything else
author: Jackie W.

description:
Really, really, really good pizza. Like really good. REALLY.

We stopped in to try this place before a Giants game, and I cannot wait to go back! I tried a slice of their regular cheese pie, and it was delicious! Not to mention ginormous! So much cheesy goodness made my heart skip a beat (pun intended)!

Slice House is a casual spot with great food/drink options, reasonable prices, and ample seating making it a new go-to before (or after) a ballgame. 


Try Slice House! You won't regret it!
author: Alexandra F.

description:
This place has some bomb ass pizzas! For a part of 4, we ended up getting two pies- wise guy and killing Zoe. 

The wise guy was meaty and Came with cream cheese which was good and filling! And killin Zoe is not for the faint of heart. I didn't feel much from the ghost pepper infused salami but my friend was DYING! It was so delicious tho. Just really oily so remember to use a napkin to soak up some oils before digging in. 

Overall, this place exceeded my expectations and was just really delicious. I would definitely come back again to try the other pizzas they have. 

Oh also they have weekend brunch!
author: April Z.

description: The pizza here is great authentic great cannot complain at all way better than Round Table Paxis  anybody  in fact anybody else they want to say lol
author: Mychelle T.

description: Pizza is really good. Unfortunately, the service is consistently awful, which makes it hard to come back regularly. I live very close by, so it's a bummer.
author: Patrick H.

description: Only ordered a slice of NY style cheese pizza. Nice thin, crust, great flavor, music was bumping and the team was really friendly even though it was a really hot day inside and out.
author: Char G.

description: The best near att ballpark. I love everything about this place. Great slices good deal.
author: Antonio V.

description: Came here a few nights ago with a friend, we came around 7 much before the kitchen closing thinking I could try to get some of the "homemade" pasta i'd seen on the menu. Instead, the guy at the front told me that the only thing they were serving was just the pizza on the counter and they weren't going to make any other pies or pasta. What a joke of a restaurant, if you've got a menu with other things on it but can't serve it when you're open then why leave it up on the first place? At one point this place had consistency but has recently turned into an establishment built on lies!
author: Ed B.

description: This is some of the best pizza and it's even better when you're on your way to a Giant's game. $5.50 for a huge slice of pepperoni is primeeeee. Come here once and it'll be a staple for future Giants games to come.
author: Joshua F.

description:
I'm from New York City and I take my pizza seriously. Yes I was skeptical of the $5+ per slice price tag, but I'm glad my pizza withdrawal drew me to Slice House. 
Big slices of pizza that look, smell, and taste delicious. You can order any of their already prepared slices and you can't go wrong. Personally, I like their pepperoni and their grandma slices. They have other items on their menu such as meatball subs.
The pizzas are all rich in flavor and the pie crust has a good combination of chewy and crunchy.  
Staff are nice and welcoming. Big tvs showing sports and ample seating. 

Definitely give it a try.
author: Patrick M.

description: This is classic Italian pizza created with a homemade sauce and thin house crust. I really enjoyed the tomato pizza however it would be great if they had at least one vegan option.
author: Melanie S.

description:
I just spent $6 for a slice of pizza. Being born and raised in NY I am a bit of a snob. And this was awful. Especially for $6 for a slice. 

Why was it awful? My whole slice smelled like burnt pizza. The weird part is the slice itself wasn't burnt. More like it was cooked in an oven where something else had recently burned. But from the moment I put it near my face, the smell overwhelmed my senses. And the odor in my nose invaded my sense of taste, and burn dominated. 

The only thing that came through was the sauce, which is way too sweet. Which is probably why I could taste it. 

$6 for a slice. Well this is San Francisco. But considering a slice of bliss in Manhattan costs half the price, this place is absurd.
author: Rich B.

description: Just tried this place out last week because of many good reviews and it's simply AWESOME! Great food. Fun atmosphere. This is pretty close though, will definitely be back.
author: Nicolas R.

description: I am a big pizza lover, so when I saw this 4 star restaurant on yelp I had to check it out. My s/o and I shared the grandma and pepperoni slices. The pepperoni was too bland for me, but the grandma was pretty good. The restaurant is cute, and they have a great selection of beers on tap.
author: Lore O.

description: Just experienced the Wise Guy Pizza at Slice House. It was terrific. Very flavorful with the right amount of toppings to compliment the pies crust. I highly recommend this experience.
author: Carlos M.

description: Stumbled on the slice house while walking towards AT&T park. Warm and inviting, greeted with a hello from staff. Flat screen TVs showing the basket ball game.. Perfect!! Select variety of pizza slices to choose from, I chose the sausage and spinach. I saw meatballs and pasta on the menu as well. Upstairs available for a small group gathering, beer and wines available too. The pizza and drinks were delicious. Nice little spot and centrally located. Be back again...
author: Thelma A.

description: Awesome stop before going to a Giants game! Great deal for a 13" pizza and a pitcher of beer. The wait wasn't terribly long, we were able to get a table right after we ordered. They had about 6-8 beers on tap and all were good options that weren't Bud light and Budweiser. The pizza was delicious and they have this red pepper olive oil at the tables that tastes sooo much better than just red pepper flakes. Try it out!
author: Alex M.

description:
The Grandma pan pizza is so damn good! And the slices here are humongous!! Totally worth it. 

Excellent place to stop by for a drink after work, or before a game. 

It's too bad they don't deliver.
author: Rie U.

description: Greasy and delicious pizza with huge slices. Also got the mixed green salad and it was really good. All the staff was friendly, especially the man at the register who told us of the deals going on that day. Already craving it again, definitely recommend :)
author: Hannah C.

description: This place ROCKS! Best deal in town and parking is soooo easy - IF THE GIANTS ARE OUT OF TOWN or if it's the off-season. Best kept secret: the pasta dishes are huge servings and very delicious. The pizzas are pretty damn good too. Excellent take out for a quick drive - after rush hour traffic.
author: Papa Dadoo B.

description:
The pizza here is amazing! The people that left negative reviews are either crazy or habitual complainers; don't believe a thing they said.
The pizza sauce is the best, not too sweet and not too acidic. The Ceasar  salad is the best I've ever had, I order it any time I go. The romaine is always fresh and I love the two different types of anchovies on top and the toast is way better than croutons!
The atmosphere is rustic and cool too.
author: Angela C.

description:
I really enjoyed my experience here...over the course of a week I had a few different pizzas: Tomato & Basil Pie, Ancient Grains Pizza (Genoa), Square Pan Pizza (Sicilian)

All these pizzas were fantastic in their own way.  Rather than the toppings being fantastic, which were still great, the dough is what really made these outstanding.  Each one was unique in their own way...flavor and texture were so interesting and something that you really focus on with each bite.  The freshness of the ingredients really comes through.

This is a great casual spot to visit...you can order for dining in or take-away, but if possible, experience the pizzas as they were meant to be experienced by dining in...you really get the authentic flavor that does seem to disappear a bit when a pre-made pizza is reheated.
author: Ken G.

description:
First things first: I have celiac disease but I'm not so sensitive that a little cross contamination will bother me. I understand their gluten free pizzas are cross contaminated. They have a warning on their menu explaining that. Ok.

So, a month ago, I went there for lunch with some coworkers, thinking I'd try their GF pizza. You can't get it by the slice. Bummer, but understandable. So I ordered a 12" gluten free pizza, thinking it'd be about enough for 1.5 meals. "That'll be $32.95," said the cashier once he'd rung me up. WTF?! An individual-sized pizza should only be $15-20, even if it's gluten free! I am not paying more than $30 for lunch. I canceled my order and walked out.

Then today a team at my office ordered pizzas from them. One of the people on the team is also gluten free, so he offered to share the GF pizza they'd gotten for him. (The order was: Popeye: White Pie, spinach, garlic, ricotta, mozzarella, and red pepper. 13" Gluten Free.) I was impressed by how puffy the crust was. Most gluten free pizzas are flat and crispy.
